Award.AwardTitle: Measurable dynamics of Polish groups and Ramsey theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Solecki will study measure preserving actions of certain large Polish groups. It is hoped that this study will uncover analogies between measurable dynamics of such groups and that of a single measure preserving transformation. This study is also expected to shed light on the structure of generic measure preserving transformations. In the second part of the project, Solecki will investigate certain combinatorial phenomena (Ramsey phenomena) that come up in connection with topological dynamics. Building on his abstract approach to Ramsey theory, he will attempt proving certain concrete Ramsey statements that have been proposed in the past. He will also attempt classification of concrete Ramsey theorems in certain limited contexts. Finally, in the third part of the project, he will work on very general, set theoretic methods (Tukey reductions) that are used to compare partial orders coming up in various areas of mathematics.

Solecki will investigate problems that involve interactions of various areas of mathematics: logic, ergodic theory, topological dynamics, and combinatorics. Three connected themes serve as both motivation for and areas of applications of the research funded by the project: study of groups of broadly understood symmetries of mathematical objects; study of generic, that is, exhibiting all possible random behavior, symmetries; and study of spaces of objects exhibiting strong forms of homogeneity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on connections between Logic, on the one hand, and Topology and Combinatorics, on the other. It used an amalgamation theory from Logic to combinatorially describe geometric and topological objects and derive topological properties of these objects. The topological objects studied in this way were simplexes, multidimensional generalizations of triangles, and the pseudoarc, a generic topological curve. For example, it was possible to find a unified approach to proving homogeneity of such objects and to lay foundation for a new combinatorial approach to basic notions of Algebraic Topology.  

The project also established connections between Ramsey theory, a branch of Combinatorics, with Topological Dynamics, Algebraic Topology, and certain orders playing an important role in parts of Set Theory. This part of the project reduced finding uniform/homogeneous structures to finding algebraic connections among algebraic structures. This reframing was used to find answers to some open questions in the area and to give a unified approach to seemingly divers problems. The algebraic structures defined in the process of this research were shown to have an independent interest. 

Two PhD students of the PI actively participated in the project. Both of them achieved their research goals and published them in internationally recognized journals. Both these students graduated and accepted postdoctoral positions at research institutions.
